From Wikipedia:

> 
> ... A **powered flyby**, or **Oberth maneuver**, describes a maneuver in which a rocket falls into a [gravitational well](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitational_well), and then accelerates when its fall reaches maximum speed. The resulting maneuver is actually a more efficient way to gain kinetic energy than applying the same impulse outside of a gravitational well. The gain in efficiency is explained by the **Oberth effect**, a phenomenon that allows employing kinetic energy to generate greater mechanical energy. In practical terms, this means that the most efficient time for a spacecraft to burn its engine is at [orbital periapse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Periapse), when its orbital velocity (and so, its kinetic energy) is greatest.

Does this also apply to a braking burn, when I want to lower my apoapsis, or is then the Oberth effect actually inverse, i.e. I expend more energy at this periapsis in order to loose kinetic energy?

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-29T14:30:54Z" title="07/29/2015 02:30  PM" data-short="8 yr">July 29, 2015</time> by Falkenherz**

The Oberth Effect benefits burns in both the prograde and retrograde directions. Capture burns are best done at low periapsis when speed is the greatest for this reason.

Edit: I wrote a little synopsis of the Oberth Effect and some of the common misconceptions about it [here](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/99758-Why-does-the-oberth-effect-work?p=1539004&viewfull=1#post1539004).
